article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, Victoria University of Wellington

author-notes.corresp: Maryanne Garry, School of Psychology, Victoria University of Wellington, P.O. Box 600, Wellington 6012, New Zealand E-mail: maryanne.garry@vuw.ac.nz

abstract.p: Deliberate and nondeliberate suggestions can influence cognitions and behaviors in surprising ways. Sometimes suggestions are helpful and improve our cognitions and behaviors, but at other times they are harmful. Suggestions can create response expectancies: the myriad ways in which we anticipate responding automatically to various situations. In this article, we discuss some of the most recent and intriguing reported effects of suggestion on cognition and behavior—effects that should make us stop and wonder, but should also make us reflect on the possibility that other well-known findings are the result of suggestion and expectation. The boundaries and underlying mechanisms of the effects of suggestion are puzzles waiting to be solved.

body.p: How could a lucky charm improve people’s performance on cognitive puzzles (Damisch, Stoberock, & Mussweiler, 2010)? Researchers have long known that expectations influence cognitions and behaviors. If I bring my rabbit’s foot to the midterm, I will do well; if I drink this vodka tonic, I will be more sociable; if I take this pill, I will feel less depressed—these are just a few examples of response expectancies, or the myriad ways in which we anticipate responding automatically to various situations (Kirsch, 1985, 1997). Expectancies do not merely shape or influence our responses: When we expect a particular outcome, we automatically set in motion a chain of cognitions and behaviors to produce that outcome—and misattribute its cause (Kirsch, 1997, 2004). A student who expects that a rabbit’s foot will help her do well on the midterm might believe more in her own abilities, have less anxiety, and persist longer on difficult questions.

Although expectancies can develop in many ways, they are often the product of suggestion (Stewart-Williams & Podd, 2004). Suggestions can come from other people or from the environment; they can be cultivated in the present or drawn from the past; and they can be deliberate or not deliberate. The effects of suggestion feature in many research domains; their most surprising and intriguing effects may make us stop in wonder, but we should also consider if other well-known findings are the result of suggestion and expectation.

sec.title: Deliberate Suggestions
sec.p: The power of suggestion can influence what are thought to be habitual cognitive responses. Take the well-known finding that people identify the ink color of a word more slowly when it does not match the color named by the word (Stroop, 1935). Telling highly suggestible people that the color words are meaningless symbols reduces this effect (Raz & Campbell, 2009; Raz, Kirsch, Pollard, & Nitkin-Kaner, 2006; but cf. Augustinova & Ferrand, 2012). Suggestions can even lead highly suggestible people to see color where there is only gray (Mazzoni et al., 2009). These findings fit with the idea that suggestion can lead people to adopt strategies that bring habitual responses under greater attentional control.

Other lines of research have examined the effects of suggestion on memory, with intriguing results. For example, giving people phony vodka tonics made them more susceptible to misleading information—but giving them a phony drug allegedly used to enhance soldiers’ performance made them less susceptible (Assefi & Garry, 2003; Clifasefi, Garry, Harper, Sharman, & Sutherland, 2007). In other words, within the same task, the opposite expectancies produced the opposite results. In another set of studies, people who were given this same phony drug were better at remembering to perform a future task (Parker, Garry, Einstein, & McDaniel, 2011). Taken together, these patterns of results point to a mechanism whereby expectancies moderate effective cognitive monitoring, and simple suggestion can thus lead to the enhancement or impairment of memory.

Suggestion can also influence implicit learning. In one study, subjects’ task was to find a target—a rotated letter T—among several distractors. Unbeknownst to the subjects, the distractors predicted the location of the target on some trials. Just before they carried out the task, subjects sniffed a cotton pad. On half of the trials, the pad was scented, and on the other half it was unscented. Depending on condition, subjects were told that the scented pad would improve their performance, that it would hurt their performance, or that it would have no effect on their performance—and that is exactly what happened: Subjects who were told that the scented pad would improve their performance found the T faster on the trials with predictive distractors, and subjects who were told that it would hurt their performance took longer (Colagiuri, Livesey, & Harris, 2010).

Suggestion also influences decisions about (and evaluations of) products. For example, when people in one study tasted two beers—one secretly infused with vinegar—they preferred the vinegar beer, even if they were told about the secret ingredient just after tasting. But when experimenters revealed the secret about the vinegar before anyone tasted the beers, the expectation that vinegar would taste bad led people to prefer the conventional beer (Lee, Frederick, & Ariely, 2006). Likewise, when students tasted unbranded chocolate and were told, either before or after tasting, that it was from Switzerland or from China, those who were told beforehand that the chocolate was Swiss reported that they liked it more (Wilcox, Roggeveen, & Grewal, 2011). Taken together, these findings show that expectations can influence evaluations of a product above and beyond its intrinsic features.

Suggestion can also influence the effectiveness of supplements and medicines. For example, in one study in which people were given a dose of the muscle relaxant carisoprodol, subjects who were told the drug was a relaxant reported feeling relaxed, and subjects who were told it was a stimulant reported feeling tense (Flaten, Simonsen, & Olsen, 1999). In another study, athletes who were given a placebo ran faster when they were told that it was a performance-enhancing drug (McClung & Collins, 2007). Intriguingly, in both these studies, people’s experiences matched their expectations, regardless of whether they consumed a placebo or an actual drug. Suggestions about price matter, too: People solved more puzzles if they were told that an energy drink they had consumed was full price than if they were told that it was discounted, and after the administration of a purported analgesic (actually just a placebo), people experienced less pain if they were told that it was full price than if they were told it was discounted (Shiv, Carmon, & Ariely, 2005; Waber, Shiv, Carmon, & Ariely, 2008). Considered together, these findings show that in some situations, people’s responses to supplements and medicines are in line with suggestions.

There is even evidence that the benefits of exercise on mental health might depend on suggestion. People undertaking an exercise program showed improvements in their self-esteem only if they were told that the program was beneficial for psychological well-being (Desharnais, Jobin, Cote, Lévesque, & Godin, 1993). One alternative explanation—that subjects whose self-esteem improved were just physically fitter and therefore mentally healthier—is untenable, because subjects showed similar increases in physical fitness regardless of what they were told. Instead, it appears that it was the expectation of improvement that led to improved psychological well-being.

sec.title: Suggestions That Are Not Deliberate
sec.p: Unintentional suggestion plays a role in both conventional and alternative medicine. Both include suggestive components that are not a part of treatment per se, such as the relationship a patient has with a practitioner (Kaptchuk et al., 2008) or the rituals of a healing procedure (Kaptchuk, 2002). In psychotherapy, for instance, clients’ expectations—often the product of a clinician’s unintentional suggestions—can influence their likelihood of staying in treatment and the likelihood of particular treatment outcomes (Greenberg, Constantino, & Bruce, 2006; Kirsch & Lynn, 1999). The relationship between expectations and outcomes is complex, poorly understood, and deserving of further investigation.

Simply observing people or otherwise making them feel special can be suggestive. People sometimes behave differently if they know they are the object of study, a finding generally known as the Hawthorne effect.1 For instance, in one study of patients with mild dementia, daily administration of Gingko biloba for 6 months had no effect over a placebo—but patients who received several intensive follow-up assessments improved more than did patients who were assessed only at the end of the study (McCarney et al., 2007). Related research has shown that when teachers hold expectations that students are high performers, they unwittingly provide those students with an enhanced learning environment that produces better performance (see Rosenthal, 2003, for a review). Taken together, these findings show that suggestions, particularly those that people do not realize they are communicating, can transmit expectations to others and thereby influence their thoughts and behaviors.

In psychological research, experimenter expectations can unintentionally influence subjects. This experimenter bias is one that most people are aware of, but the phenomenon is not restricted to psychological scientists. Unintentional suggestion wields influence in the justice system, too. Judges, for example, can communicate their expectations and influence juror verdicts. In one study, when mock jurors watched judges giving jury instructions, their verdicts matched the judges’ private expectations (Hart, 1995), and a meta-analysis of four studies showed that judges’ expectations were powerful enough to tip the balance in jurors’ verdicts—making a relatively unlikely guilty verdict relatively likely (Rosenthal, 2003). But there is even more alarming evidence of the influence of suggestion in the justice system. Data from laboratory studies and the criminal justice system show that when lineups are conducted by people who know who the suspects are, the rate of false identifications of innocent people can skyrocket to more than 300 percent the rate of false identification when lineups are double-blind (Loftus, Wells, & Stahl, 2012).

Many unintentional suggestions result in irrational expectations, such as superstitions—but superstitions can have positive effects. People make more successful putts when they are told that a golf ball is lucky, solve motor-dexterity puzzles better when experimenters make a “good luck” hand gesture, and shine on a memory game when they are in the presence of their lucky charm (Damisch et al., 2010). Together, these findings show that superstitious expectations—despite being irrational—can have a positive impact on cognition and behavior.

Although the effects of suggestion can be powerful, they do not always work, and sometimes they can even backfire. For example, if a suggestion calls for too drastic a change in experience, its effects can be reversed; suggestions can also change a person’s subjective experience without affecting its underlying physical function (Kirsch & Weixel, 1988; Wechsler et al., 2011). At other times, suggestion’s effects are surprisingly strong, rivaling the effects of active medication and surgical procedures (Kaptchuk et al., 2008; Kirsch et al., 2008; Moseley et al., 2002).

sec.title: Response Expectancy Theory
sec.p: How do we make sense of these wide-ranging effects? One of the prevailing explanations comes from Response Expectancy Theory (Kirsch, 1985). According to this theory, expectancies can directly alter our subjective experience of internal states. In addition, when we expect a particular outcome, we sometimes unwittingly behave so as to produce that outcome (Kirsch, 1985, 1997; Kirsch & Lynn, 1999). For instance, when people take the phony cognition-enhancing drug R273, they tend to expect it to improve their alertness, so they engage in more effortful monitoring but misattribute their improved performance to R273 (Clifasefi et al., 2007).

These misattributions fit with copious research showing that people are often completely unaware of why they did what they just did. Their introspections come not from insight but from preformed ideas about causality (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977; Wilson & Bar-Anan, 2008). For example, people who took R273 reported enhanced cognitive and perceptual abilities, reporting “greatly increased clarity of vision” (Parker, 2009, p. 53) and feelings of being “much more alert” and “much more focused” (p. 73; see also Parker, Garry, Engle, Harper, & Clifasefi, 2008). These comments illustrate a fundamental fact about expectancies: People can access and report their expectancies when their attention is directed to their behavior (Kirsch, 2004).

Accordingly, expectancy effects differ from other automatic behavioral responses, such as those produced by embodied cognition—the idea that cognitions and behaviors are intimately linked with bodily states and sensory experiences—or priming (for a review, see Meier, Schnall, Schwarz, & Bargh, in press). Take, for example, the finding that physical warmth influences interpersonal warmth. When subjects were given a hot cup of coffee, they judged a target person’s personality to be warmer than did subjects who were given iced coffee (Williams & Bargh, 2008a). However, when questioned, the subjects revealed that they were all completely unaware of the expected influence of the cup of coffee. By contrast, expectancy effects operate precisely because people link a stimulus with its inevitable outcome. Expectancy effects differ from volitional responses, too, because people think that expectancy-driven behaviors are automatic. Intriguingly, the only real separation between an expectancy effect and a “volitional” act may be the subjective experience of volition; research highlights the possibility that all behavior we experience as voluntary is in fact automatic (Bargh, 2008; Kirsch & Lynn, 1999).

sec.title: Why You Should Care
sec.p: Given the ubiquitous effects of suggestion, should we worry that some of psychological science’s well-known effects are really the result of unintentional suggestion? Take, for example, the well-documented finding that self-control is a depletable resource (for a review, see Baumeister, Gailliot, DeWall, & Oaten, 2006). Recent research has not only failed to find evidence for this depletion account (Healey, Hasher, & Danilova, 2011), it has also shown that self-control is depleted only if people expect it to be—either because they already hold that view or because it is explicitly suggested to them (Job, Dweck, & Walton, 2010).

In another, highly publicized study, training people on demanding working memory tasks led to improvements in fluid intelligence: the ability to reason and solve problems (Jaeggi, Buschkuehl, Jonides, & Perrig, 2008). An alternative explanation is that the people who received training showed a Hawthorne effect: They were treated differently. In essence, we cannot determine whether the results were due to the training itself or to people’s expectations about how they should behave over the course of training. Because there was no control group that was trained for an equal amount of time on tasks that are not purported to improve fluid intelligence, teasing apart these competing explanations is not possible.

These examples warrant vigilance in detecting the unwanted effects of suggestion and are worthy of further discussion in the scientific community—perhaps as part of the scientific community’s discussion about fraudulent data, less-than-optimal experimental design, and publication bias (see Simmons, Nelson, & Simonsohn, 2011, and the February 2012 Observer). These discussions have prompted renewed interest in the value of replication, including research at the intersection of suggestion, cognition, and behavior. Take, for instance, one study reporting that hotel-room attendants who were told that their work was good exercise lost body fat and lowered their blood pressure, even though they reported not exercising more or eating less than a control group (Crum & Langer, 2007). These findings fit with the idea that adopting a particular mind-set can produce expectations that may affect a person’s physiology. However, two attempts to replicate those results have failed (Beauchamp et al., 2011; Stanforth, Steinhardt, Mackert, Stanforth, & Gloria, 2011).

A more comprehensive approach to replication is provided by www.psychfiledrawer.org, an online database of replication attempts, including failures. Recent entries include failures to replicate well-known findings from the goal-priming literature (Bargh, Chen, & Burrows, 1996; Williams & Bargh, 2008b). Other researchers have recently published reports of similar failures to replicate those findings—and have implicated the role of expectancy effects in the original findings (Doyen, Klein, Pichon, & Cleeremans, 2012; but see Bargh, 2012a, 2012b). We suspect that sometimes, a failure to replicate might signal that a reported effect was tied to a laboratory—in other words, it was the product of unwittingly transmitted (and therefore undocumented) expectancies.

sec.title: Current Directions
sec.p: Despite the prevalence of the effects of suggestion, our limited knowledge of how and why they function shows that we have not given them the attention they deserve. Reflecting on these effects causes several important questions to emerge. Why do they happen at all? How is it that a simple suggestion can influence our cognitions, perceptions, and behaviors? Can we improve people’s lives by harnessing the power of suggestion? What are the boundaries and limitations of these effects? What is the difference between a “real” treatment and a “suggestion”? Suggestion can exert a powerful influence on how we think, feel, and act. The boundaries and underlying mechanisms of these effects are fascinating puzzles waiting to be solved.

sec.title: Recommended Reading
sec.p: Hull, J. G., & Bond, C. F. (1986). Social and behavioral consequences of alcohol consumption and expectancy: A meta-analysis. Psychological Bulletin, 99, 347–360. doi:10.1037/0033-2909.99.3.347. A review of research investigating the role of expectancies in alcohol consumption that provided the impetus for later research in areas beyond addiction.

Kirsch, I. (2010). The emperor’s new drugs: Exploding the antidepressant myth. New York, NY: Basic Books. A book that focuses particularly on the role of placebo effects in responses to antidepressants but also offers a thorough, accessible review of placebo effects in general.

Price, D. D., Finniss, D. G., & Benedetti, F. (2008). A comprehensive review of the placebo effect: Recent advances and current thought. Annual Review of Psychology, 59, 565–590. doi:10.1146/annurev.psych.59.113006.095941. A detailed examination of the placebo effect, including possible mechanisms.

Rohsenow, D. J., & Marlatt, G. A. (1981). The balanced placebo design: Methodological considerations. Addictive Behaviors, 6, 107–122. doi:10.1016/0306-4603(81)90003-4. A classic work in the field describing a pioneering experimental approach to studying expectancy effects.
Stewart-Williams, S., & Podd, J. (2004). (See References). A review examining different accounts of expectancy effects, including Response Expectancy Theory as well as alternative views.

ack.p: The authors thank Brian Ostafin and Hal Pashler for their helpful comments. This article is dedicated to Alan Marlatt, who died in March 2011. In addition to being a pioneer in addiction research and an advocate of harm reduction, he also helped develop the Balanced Placebo Design—the gold-standard means of investigating the separate psychological and physiological components of the effects of substances such as alcohol. In 1993, in an enormous act of generosity, Marlatt worked with Beth Loftus to give Maryanne Garry her first academic job as a postdoc in the Addictive Behaviors Research Center at the University of Washington.

fn.p: The authors declared that they had no conflicts of interest with respect to their authorship or the publication of this article.

The authors are grateful for the support of the New Zealand Government through the Marsden Fund, administered by the Royal Society of New Zealand on behalf of the Marsden Fund Council. Robert Michael gratefully acknowledges support from Victoria University of Wellington.

Intriguingly, the Hawthorne effect itself has a surprisingly rocky history. The effect is named after the Hawthorne Works of the Western Electric Company, a factory where research on worker productivity was conducted in the 1920s and ’30s. But as research has shown (Adair, 1984; Wickström & Bendix, 2000), reports of these studies—often included in textbooks—are riddled with errors that dramatically limit the inferences that can be drawn from them: variables (such as music) are described as having been manipulated, but they never were; female workers are sometimes described as men; and one reference even describes Hawthorne as the town where the studies took place, rather than the name of the plant.
